title: Introduction to First World War Tour
description: An introduction to some of the themes you'll discover on this tour and how to follow it on your device. The trail covers all three floors of the Museum. The tracks lasts 1-2 minutes each and are voiced by some of the Museum’s knowledgeable volunteer guides - Helen, Lucy and Lizzy. We hope you enjoy it.

title: Horned Naga dance helmet
description: A century ago, the Naga people of northeast India still practised head-hunting. Sometimes they decorated the skulls of enemies with horns and tassels to make a dance accessory. As part of British-ruled India, Naga units fought on the Western Front and this German 'Pickelhaube' helmet was taken instead of a head and decorated as a souvenir or trophy.
hint: This object is in the front of the case as you have you back to the entrance.

title: Arthur Kennedy's mandolin
description: Mandolin owned by a music teacher, Arthur Kennedy, 'minstrel' within the Ox and Bucks Light Infantry (OBLI) during the War. The names of significant battles such as Piave and Ypres are written down the side.
hint: This object is in the side of the Lutes display on the middle shelf.

title: Trench art - vases
description: Brass cases from British and French artillery shells, recycled into decorative vases as part of a fashion for 'trench art' during and after the War.
hint: This object is on the bottom of the free-standing recycling case as you have your back to the gallery entrance.

title: Emergency money
description: The conditions of war led to a shortage of coined money. Bus tickets and postage stamps printed on stout paper were a good temporary substitute. These stamps depict three Tsars of Russia - Alexander I, Nicholas I and Nicholas II.
hint: This object is in the very last case of a run of desktop cases devoted to currency.

title: Trench art - cap and ashtray
description: During the War there was a fashion for 'trench art' made from reclaimed armament materials. This miniature cap incorporates the base of a French brass shell and a German Imperial button as a badge.
hint: This is the round brass object in the upright case facing you as you enter the gallery.

title: Officers' weapons
description: Several weapons have become associated with the First World War. These include the German officers' Luger pistol (later outlawed as part of the Versailles agreement), the British officers' Webley-Pryse revolver, and the easy-to-use infantryman's SMLE ('smelly') rifle.
hint: This object is in the desktop case facing you as you enter the gallery.

title: Humane animal killer
description: Millions of horses were used, maimed and killed during the War. In 1895 Birmingham gunmaker W. W. Greener invented the world’s first humane animal killer, which was later adopted by the War Office and Admiralty. The device was hit on the end with a mallet, firing a bullet into the animal’s skull and killing it instantly.
hint: This object is in the far left desktop case facing you as you enter the gallery.

title: Conscientious objector's revolver
description: A small nickel-plated Liege pocket revolver, designed for concealment, belonging to a German conscientious objector.
hint: Stand with your back to the shields and this object is at the bottom edge of the desktop display of revolvers.

title: Jibbah with bullet hole
description: Quilted coat known as a 'jibbah', worn on horseback by a Sufi Muslim warrior and with a bullet hole in the chest. It was retrieved from the battlefield at Omdurman, Sudan (1898), where the British army routed a Mahdist uprising and ushered in 20th-century mechanised warfare.
hint: This object is located halfway along this gallery in the wall cases to your left.

title: Sniper's helmet
description: German sniper's helmet, painted by the owner. Metal helmets were introduced in 1916 shortly followed by camouflaged versions to blend into the brown and green surrounds of a shooter's typical hideout in a thicket.
hint: This object is in the corner of this gallery, near the bottom of a display of helmets.

title: Trench knife
description: Push knife (part-dagger, part-knuckleduster) used in trench raids. A non-standard issue item, manufacturered in response to a demand for self-defence weapons. This example, made of aluminium (and therefore light to carry), was made in Dudley, Worcestershire.
hint: This object is sitting on a cane shelf halfway downt the case, listed as no. 32

title: Amulets
description: Two religious amulets depicting the Virgin Mary and the Pascal Lamb, used as personal objects of luck and devotion during the War.
hint: These objects are situated in the far corner of the gallery, in a desktop case numbered U.60.A.
